conclusion: The problem involves calculating the magnitude of the Ampere force acting on a current-carrying wire in a uniform magnetic field.

The force on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is given by the formula F = (1/2) * I * B * L * v, where I is the current, B is the magnetic induction intensity, L is the length of the wire, and v is the velocity of the wire.
The given parameters are: length of the wire L = 3L, magnetic induction intensity B, and current I.
The velocity v can be assumed to be constant for simplicity.
Since the wire is folded into a right-angle shape, the velocity v can be calculated using the formula v = L/t, where t is the time taken to complete one cycle of the wire.
The time t is equal to the length of the wire divided by the speed of light c, so t = L/c.
Substituting t = L/c into v = L/t gives v = L/c.
Substitute the values into the force formula: F = (1/2) * I * B * L * v.
Substitute L = 3L, B = B, and v = L/c into the formula: F = (1/2) * I * B * 3L * (L/c).
Simplify the expression to get F = (3/2) * I * B * L.
The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the current-carrying wire is (3/2) * I * B * L.
